comments.body:
why is this needed? we don't appear to be populating it at all

(also arrays in bash is a sign to start considering something other than bash)
because it will be needed for apiextensions-apiserver (follow-up PR) which needs autoscaling/v1 as additional group.

> also arrays in bash is a sign to start considering something other than bash

It's our choice in k8s.io/code-generator for project not using kubebuilder.

The `declare -a` makes sure that `${OPENAPI_EXTRA_PACKAGES[@]}` in the next line does not fail when the variable is empty.

Yeah, I understand this is the language you're locked into, and it's a sane/clean declaration given that constraint. I just wanted to make sure this wasn't something being left around just incase, follow on makes sense.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +113,117 @@if [ "${GENS}" = "all" ] || grep -qw "openapi" <<<"${GENS}"; then
  echo "Generating OpenAPI definitions for ${GROUPS_WITH_VERSIONS} at ${OUTPUT_PKG}/openapi"
  declare -a OPENAPI_EXTRA_PACKAGES
  "${GOPATH}/bin/openapi-gen" \
           --input-dirs "$(codegen::join , "${EXT_FQ_APIS[@]}" "${OPENAPI_EXTRA_PACKAGES[@]}")" \

comments.body: what does this do? This need a comment, if at all necessary.

ref: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/73246#discussion_r250457620 .
If we using a tmp array then can fix this issue.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +88,92 @@  echo "Generating clientset for ${GROUPS_WITH_VERSIONS} at ${OUTPUT_PKG}/${CLIENTSET_PKG_NAME:-clientset}"
  if [ -n "${INT_APIS_PKG}" ]; then
    IFS=" " read -r -a APIS <<< "$(printf '%s/ ' "${INT_FQ_APIS[@]}")"
    "${GOPATH}/bin/client-gen" --clientset-name "${CLIENTSET_NAME_INTERNAL:-internalversion}" --input-base "" --input "$(codegen::join , "${APIS[@]}")" --output-package "${OUTPUT_PKG}/${CLIENTSET_PKG_NAME:-clientset}" "$@"
  fi
